title: Shailene Woodley
text:
Shailene Diann Woodley (born November 15, 1991) is an American actress. Born in <a href="San%20Bernardino%2C%20California">San Bernardino, California</a>, and raised in <a href="Simi%20Valley%2C%20California">Simi Valley</a>, Woodley started modeling at the age of four and began acting professionally in minor television roles. She first gained prominence for her starring role as <a href="Amy%20Juergens">Amy Juergens</a> in the <a href="ABC%20Family">ABC Family</a> drama series "<a href="The%20Secret%20Life%20of%20the%20American%20Teenager">The Secret Life of the American Teenager</a>" (2008–2013).
Woodley made her film debut in "<a href="The%20Descendants">The Descendants</a>" in 2011, and went on to star in the coming-of-age film "<a href="The%20Spectacular%20Now">The Spectacular Now</a>" (2013). For the former, she won a <a href="Troph%C3%A9e%20Chopard">Cannes Trophée Chopard</a> and received a nomination for the <a href="Golden%20Globe%20Award%20for%20Best%20Supporting%20Actress%20%E2%80%93%20Motion%20Picture">Golden Globe Award for Best Supporting Actress – Motion Picture</a>. For the latter, she won a special jury prize at the <a href="Sundance%20Film%20Festival">Sundance Film Festival</a>. She achieved wider recognition for her starring role as a teenaged cancer patient in the romantic drama <a href="The%20Fault%20in%20Our%20Stars%20%28film%29">"The Fault in Our Stars"</a> (2014) and as <a href="Beatrice%20Prior">Beatrice Prior</a> in the science-fiction trilogy "<a href="The%20Divergent%20Series">The Divergent Series</a>" (2014–2016). From 2017 to 2019, she played a sexual assault survivor in the <a href="HBO">HBO</a> drama series "<a href="Big%20Little%20Lies%20%28TV%20series%29">Big Little Lies</a>", for which she was nominated for a <a href="Primetime%20Emmy%20Award%20for%20Outstanding%20Supporting%20Actress%20in%20a%20Limited%20Series%20or%20Movie">Primetime Emmy Award</a> and a <a href="Golden%20Globe%20Award%20for%20Best%20Supporting%20Actress%20%E2%80%93%20Series%2C%20Miniseries%20or%20Television%20Film">Golden Globe Award</a>. In 2021 she starred in the critically acclaimed drama films "<a href="The%20Mauritanian">The Mauritanian</a>" and <a href="The%20Fallout%20%28film%29">"The Fallout"</a>.
Woodley is also an environmental activist and serves as a board member of the <a href="political%20action%20committee">political action committee</a> <a href="Our%20Revolution">Our Revolution</a>.
Early life.
Woodley was raised in <a href="Simi%20Valley%2C%20California">Simi Valley, California</a>. Her mother, Lori ("<a href="Given%20name">née</a>" Victor), is a <a href="school%20counselor">school counselor</a>, and her father, Lonnie Woodley, a <a href="Head%20teacher">school principal</a>. She has a younger brother.
At 15, she was diagnosed with <a href="scoliosis">scoliosis</a> and was put in a chest-to-hips plastic brace to stop her spine from curving further. Woodley attended <a href="Simi%20Valley%20High%20School">Simi Valley High School</a> and also took acting classes from <a href="Anthony%20Meindl">Anthony Meindl</a>.
Career.
1999–2010: Career beginnings and "Secret Life".
Woodley began her acting career in 1999 with a minor role in the television film "<a href="Replacing%20Dad">Replacing Dad</a>". She went on to feature in minor television roles in "<a href="The%20District">The District</a>" and "<a href="Crossing%20Jordan">Crossing Jordan</a>" (in the latter, she portrayed the 10-year-old version of <a href="Jill%20Hennessy">Jill Hennessy</a>'s title character). She followed with a leading role in the television film "A Place Called Home" (2004) as California Ford, which earned her a nomination for a <a href="Young%20Artist%20Award">Young Artist Award</a> for <a href="26th%20Young%20Artist%20Awards">Best Leading Young Actress in a TV Movie, Miniseries or Special</a>. She also originally played the young <a href="Kaitlin%20Cooper">Kaitlin Cooper</a> in "<a href="The%20O.C.">The O.C.</a>" and appeared as the titular character Felicity Merriman in the television film "" (2005). Her performance received another Young Artist Award nomination, this time for Best Performance in a TV Movie, Miniseries, or Special (Comedy or Drama). Following this, Woodley appeared in numerous guest roles in other television series, including "<a href="Everybody%20Loves%20Raymond">Everybody Loves Raymond</a>," "<a href="My%20Name%20is%20Earl">My Name is Earl</a>," "," "<a href="Close%20to%20Home%20%282005%20TV%20series%29">Close to Home</a>," and "<a href="Cold%20Case%20%28TV%20series%29">Cold Case</a>."
Woodley was then cast as the main character, Amy Juergens, in the ABC Family series "<a href="The%20Secret%20Life%20of%20the%20American%20Teenager">The Secret Life of the American Teenager</a>" (2008–2013), about a 15-year-old girl who learns she is pregnant. The show explores the effects of her pregnancy on her family, friends, and herself, as well as life at <a href="Grant%20High%20School%20%28Los%20Angeles%29">Grant High School</a>. Ken Tucker of "<a href="Entertainment%20Weekly">Entertainment Weekly</a>" praised her performance, stating, "[It] lifts a well-meaning, rather brave, but ramshackle show a notch." Popular among viewers, the show became one of ABC Family's most-watched telecasts throughout its five-season run, spanning over 121 episodes.
2011–2014: Film debut and breakthrough.
In 2011, Woodley made her feature film debut in "The Descendants," where she played Alex, the troubled elder daughter of Matt King (played by <a href="George%20Clooney">George Clooney</a>). Her performance received positive reviews from critics. <a href="A.%20O.%20Scott">A. O. Scott</a> from "<a href="The%20New%20York%20Times">The New York Times</a>" said, "Ms. Woodley [gives] one of the toughest, smartest, most credible adolescent performances in recent memory." Peter Debruge from "<a href="Variety%20%28magazine%29">Variety</a>" said that her performance is a "revelation" and that "in the role of Alex, [she is] displaying both the edge and depth the role demands." Following accolades for her performance, Woodley received a Golden Globe nomination for <a href="Golden%20Globe%20Award%20for%20Best%20Supporting%20Actress%26amp%3Bnbsp%3B%E2%80%93%20Motion%20Picture">Best Supporting Actress – Motion Picture</a>, and won the <a href="Independent%20Spirit%20Award%20for%20Best%20Supporting%20Female">Independent Spirit Award for Best Supporting Female</a>. "<a href="People%20%28magazine%29">People</a>" named her one of 2012's "Most Beautiful at Every Age." Woodley was also considered one of the 55 faces of the future by "<a href="Nylon%20Magazine">Nylon</a>" "Young Hollywood Issue".
Woodley starred in the <a href="The%20Spectacular%20Now">film adaptation</a> of Tim Tharp's novel, "The Spectacular Now," as Aimee Finecky, an innocent, bookish teenager who begins dating the charming, freewheeling high-school senior (<a href="Miles%20Teller">Miles Teller</a>). The film premiered at <a href="Sundance%20Festival">Sundance</a> on January 18, 2013. Her portrayal of Aimee garnered much praise; "<a href="Los%20Angeles%20Times">Los Angeles Times</a>"' critic Betsy Sharkey said that Woodley and Teller "bring such an authentic face of confidence and questioning, indifference and need, pain and denial, friendship and first love," while another critic from "<a href="The%20Guardian">The Guardian</a>" said that they gave "remarkably strong performances" that "display a depth of feeling that's breathtaking in its simplicity and honest[y]." Additionally, Woodley won the <a href="List%20of%20Sundance%20Film%20Festival%20award%20winners%232013">Special Jury Award for Acting</a>, alongside Teller, at the <a href="2013%20Sundance%20Film%20Festival">2013 Sundance Film Festival</a> and received a nomination for the <a href="Independent%20Spirit%20Award%20for%20Best%20Female%20Lead">Independent Spirit Award for Best Female Lead</a>.
In October 2012, Woodley was offered the role of <a href="Mary%20Jane%20Watson">Mary Jane Watson</a> in "<a href="The%20Amazing%20Spider-Man%202">The Amazing Spider-Man 2</a>." On June 19, 2013, she was cut from the film. Director <a href="Marc%20Webb">Marc Webb</a> told "<a href="The%20Hollywood%20Reporter">The Hollywood Reporter</a>" that the cut was "a creative decision to streamline the story and focus on <a href="Spider-Man">Peter</a> and <a href="Gwen%20Stacy">Gwen</a> and their relationship," and that everyone loved working with Woodley. She had also signed on to star in "<a href="White%20Bird%20in%20a%20Blizzard">White Bird in a Blizzard</a>," directed by <a href="Gregg%20Araki">Gregg Araki</a>. Although filming took place in October 2012, the film was not released until January 20, 2014, at the <a href="2014%20Sundance%20Film%20Festival">Sundance Film Festival</a> and then on October 24, 2014, to wider audiences, where it received mixed reviews. In the film, she plays teenager Katrina "Kat" Connors, whose life is thrown into chaos when her mother disappears. Critic Moira MacDonald commended her by saying, "Woodley's depiction of Kat is low-key, natural, and utterly unaffected; as she has in every role, she makes the character her own, with her scratchy little voice and level gaze."
In 2014, Woodley starred as <a href="Tris%20Prior">Beatrice "Tris" Prior</a> in the film "<a href="Divergent%20%28film%29">Divergent</a>," an adaptation of <a href="Veronica%20Roth">Veronica Roth</a>'s best-selling <a href="Divergent%20%28novel%29">young-adult novel of the same name</a>, and the first installment in "The Divergent Series." Set in a <a href="dystopian">dystopian</a> and <a href="postapocalyptic">postapocalyptic</a> <a href="Chicago">Chicago</a>, the film received mixed reviews, but Woodley's performance as Tris received a positive reception; Sam Allard from "<a href="Orlando%20Weekly">Orlando Weekly</a>" said, "with her performance as Tris Prior in "Divergent," Woodley rescues and then raises up a film that could have been an utter disaster." "Divergent" reached the number-one spot at the box office during its opening weekend, and was a financial success.
Also in 2014, Woodley starred as Hazel Grace Lancaster in "<a href="The%20Fault%20in%20Our%20Stars%20%28film%29">The Fault in Our Stars</a>," the film adaptation of <a href="John%20Green%20%28author%29">John Green</a>'s <a href="The%20Fault%20in%20Our%20Stars">novel of the same name</a>. She portrayed a 16-year-old cancer patient who meets and falls in love with Augustus Waters (<a href="Ansel%20Elgort">Ansel Elgort</a>, who also played her brother in the "Divergent" series), a similarly afflicted teen from her cancer support group. Green said via <a href="Twitter">Twitter</a> about Woodley; "There were so many amazing auditions for the role of Hazel, but Shailene's love for the book and her understanding of Hazel blew me away." The film was a blockbuster success, grossing over $307 million worldwide. Woodley's performance received critical acclaim from critics; Peter Travers in "<a href="Rolling%20Stones">Rolling Stone</a>" called her a "sublime actress with a résumé that pretty much proves she's incapable of making a false move on camera", and <a href="Richard%20Roeper">Richard Roeper</a> of "<a href="Chicago%20Sun-Times">Chicago Sun-Times</a>" called her performance as Hazel Oscar-worthy, adding, "she's that memorable". On November 14, 2014, she received <a href="18th%20Hollywood%20Film%20Awards">The Hollywood Film Award</a> for Hollywood Breakout Performance – Actress for her depiction of Hazel.
2015–present: Further film and television work.
In 2015, Woodley reprised her role as Tris in "," the second installment in "The Divergent Series." Her performance once again received critical acclaim, with Daniel M. Kimmel of "New England Movies Weekly" writing, "Woodley does solid work here as she's done elsewhere, and continues to be someone to watch." Despite a more negative critical reception than the previous film, "Insurgent" was commercially successful, making nearly $100 million in its worldwide debut and grossed $295.2 million worldwide. She reprised her role again in the penultimate film of the series "" (2016). The film, however, was poorly reviewed by critics and a <a href="box-office%20bomb">box-office bomb</a>. Lionsgate had planned for the final film in the series to be made for television, but Woodley announced that she would not be a part of it. She next starred opposite <a href="Joseph%20Gordon-Levitt">Joseph Gordon-Levitt</a> in <a href="Oliver%20Stone">Oliver Stone</a>'s biographical thriller "<a href="Snowden%20%28film%29">Snowden</a>" (2016), in which Gordon-Levitt portrayed <a href="Edward%20Snowden">Edward Snowden</a>. Owen Gleiberman's review said that Woodley "gives a performance of breathtaking dimension: As the movie goes on, she makes Lindsay supportive and selfish, loving and stricken."
Starting in 2015, Woodley took a break from filming for nearly a year, stating in a later interview that she "had hit a wall with acting." From 2017 to 2019, Woodley starred as a sexual assault survivor, alongside <a href="Nicole%20Kidman">Nicole Kidman</a> and <a href="Reese%20Witherspoon">Reese Witherspoon</a>, in two seasons of the <a href="HBO">HBO</a> drama series "Big Little Lies". She was nominated for an Emmy and Golden Globe Award in 2017 for Best Supporting Actress in a Limited Series or Movie and Best Performance by an Actress in a Supporting Role in a Series, Limited Series or Motion Picture Made for Television respectively for her role. She also starred in and produced the biographical film "<a href="Adrift%20%282018%20film%29">Adrift</a>" (2018), with <a href="Baltasar%20Korm%C3%A1kur">Baltasar Kormákur</a> as director. Daniel Feingold from <a href="WSVN">WSVN</a> called her performance as <a href="Tami%20Oldham%20Ashcraft">Tami Oldham Ashcraft</a>, a real-life sailor who was stranded at sea after a storm, "Oscar-worthy". Woodley was awarded the Rising Star Award during the 2018 <a href="Deauville%20Film%20Festival">Deauville Film Festival</a>.
In 2019, Woodley starred in the romantic drama "<a href="Endings%2C%20Beginnings">Endings, Beginnings</a>" alongside <a href="Sebastian%20Stan">Sebastian Stan</a>, <a href="Jamie%20Dornan">Jamie Dornan</a>, and <a href="Matthew%20Gray%20Gubler">Matthew Gray Gubler</a>. In 2021, she starred in the real-life <a href="Guantanamo%20Bay">Guantanamo Bay</a> drama film "<a href="The%20Mauritanian">The Mauritanian</a>" alongside <a href="Jodie%20Foster">Jodie Foster</a>, <a href="Tahar%20Rahim">Tahar Rahim</a> and <a href="Benedict%20Cumberbatch">Benedict Cumberbatch</a> and also had a small supporting role in the critically acclaimed film "<a href="The%20Fallout%20%28film%29">The Fallout</a>". She also starred in the romantic drama film "<a href="The%20Last%20Letter%20from%20Your%20Lover">The Last Letter from Your Lover</a>" alongside <a href="Felicity%20Jones">Felicity Jones</a>, based on the bestselling book by <a href="Jojo%20Moyes">Jojo Moyes</a>.
Upcoming projects.
She will next star in "<a href="Misanthrope%20%28film%29">Misanthrope</a>", an upcoming thriller centered on a talented but troubled cop who is recruited by the FBI to help profile and track down a serial killer. The film is set to be directed by <a href="Dami%C3%A1n%20Szifron">Damián Szifron</a>. Woodley will serve as a producer on the film. She will star in the <a href="Thriller%20film">thriller</a> "Panopticon" with <a href="Anthony%20Mackie">Anthony Mackie</a> and <a href="Jacob%20Latimore">Jacob Latimore</a>, which began filming in <a href="New%20Mexico">New Mexico</a> in summer 2021. She joined <a href="Jack%20Whitehall">Jack Whitehall</a> in the upcoming <a href="comedy">comedy</a> film "Robots", which was slated to begin filming in <a href="New%20Mexico">New Mexico</a> in August 2021. She is set to star in the upcoming <a href="Showtime%20%28TV%20network%29">Showtime</a> hourlong drama series "Three Women", based on the award-winning and bestselling book by <a href="Lisa%20Taddeo">Lisa Taddeo</a>. Filming was set to begin in Fall 2021. She was also cast in "Girl Named Sue", a film based on the true story of Sue Webber-Brown, a <a href="DEA">DEA</a> agent who created the Drug Endangered Children (DEC) protocol. She joined <a href="Shia%20Lebeouf">Shia Lebeouf</a> and <a href="Robert%20De%20Niro">Robert De Niro</a> in the upcoming crime drama "After Exile", with <a href="Joshua%20Michael%20Stern">Joshua Michael Stern</a> as director. In November 2020, she joined "The Fence", a <a href="political%20satire">political satire</a> film that will reunite her with Miles Teller for their fifth film. The film will be directed by <a href="Gr%C3%ADmur%20H%C3%A1konarson">Grímur Hákonarson</a>. She will star in the animated feature "Scarygirl" and romance film "No Baggage", which are in pre-production and development respectively.
Personal life.
In 2018, Woodley confirmed she was dating Australian-Fijian <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> player <a href="Ben%20Volavola">Ben Volavola</a>. In an interview with "<a href="The%20Hollywood%20Reporter">The Hollywood Reporter</a>", she said: "I fall in love with human beings based on who they are, not based on what they do or what sex they are". In April 2020, the relationship with Volavola was reported to have ended.
Woodley was reported to have been in a relationship with NFL <a href="quarterback">quarterback</a> <a href="Aaron%20Rodgers">Aaron Rodgers</a> since 2020. In February 2021, Rodgers referred to his "fiancée" during his acceptance speech for the league's <a href="National%20Football%20League%20Most%20Valuable%20Player%20Award">MVP award</a> at the <a href="10th%20Annual%20NFL%20Honors">NFL Honors</a> ceremony, confirming that he was engaged, but not to whom. Woodley confirmed she was engaged to Rodgers in a February 22, 2021 appearance on "<a href="The%20Tonight%20Show%20Starring%20Jimmy%20Fallon">The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon</a>".
Activism.
Woodley is an avid <a href="Environmentalism">environmental activist</a> and climate advocate. In 2010 she and her mother co-founded the nonprofit organization All it Takes, a youth leadership program that aims to educate young people to practice empathy, compassion, responsibility, and purpose in hopes to foster sustainable, positive change for themselves, others and the environment. She supported <a href="Bernie%20Sanders">Bernie Sanders</a> for president in 2016 and 2020.
In 2016, Woodley <a href="Dakota%20Access%20Pipeline%20protests">protested</a> against the <a href="Dakota%20Access%20Pipeline">Dakota Access Pipeline</a>, an underground petroleum transport pipeline. In October, she was arrested for criminal trespassing in <a href="Saint%20Anthony%2C%20North%20Dakota">Saint Anthony, North Dakota</a>. She pleaded guilty and was sentenced to a year of probation.
In mid-2016, Woodley joined the board of <a href="Our%20Revolution">Our Revolution</a>, a political organization aimed to educate voters about issues, get people involved in the political process, support progressive policies such as <a href="Medicare%20for%20All">Medicare for All</a>, and work to organize and elect <a href="Progressivism">progressive</a> leaders.
On September 29, 2016, Woodley was honored at the 20th Anniversary Global Green Environmental Awards, receiving the Entertainment Industry Environmental Leadership Award for co-founding All it Takes. In October 2016, she was given the Female EMA Futures Award during the 26th Annual <a href="Environmental%20Media%20Association">Environmental Media Association (EMA)</a> Awards.
In 2018, Woodley took activist Calina Lawrence to the <a href="75th%20Golden%20Globe%20Awards">75th Golden Globe Awards</a> as her guest; they met at <a href="Standing%20Rock">Standing Rock</a> while protesting the Dakota Access Pipeline.
In July 2019, Woodley became an Oceans Ambassador for <a href="Greenpeace">Greenpeace</a> and embarked on a three-week-long expedition to the <a href="Sargasso%20Sea">Sargasso Sea</a> to study the impact of plastics and <a href="microplastic">microplastic</a>s on marine life, and to document the importance of this unique ecosystem for protection under a new global ocean <a href="treaty">treaty</a> that is being negotiated at the <a href="United%20Nations">United Nations</a>.
